These vulnerabilities aren\u2019t sexy, cool, or new, we\u2019ve known about them for years, but they\u2019re everywhere! The scale of GitHub and tools like CodeQL enable one to scan for vulnerabilities across hundreds of thousands of OSS projects, but the challenge is how to scale the triaging, reporting, and fixing. n this session, Jonathan Leitschuh will cover a highly scalable solution for fixing vulnerabilities\u2014automated bulk pull request generation. Jonathan will discuss the practical applications of this technique on real-world OSS projects. I\u00b4d like to share my experience as a joiner in new projects who have to deal with this complexity for the beginning.\n\nIf you only use git to commit your changes and allow it to integrate, you\u00b4re probably losing the opportunity to take advantage of all the things that you can do with git. When I used to teach git to young developers I say git is more than six commands, because it's about how you and your team are building software. So using git you\u00b4re able to discover all the collaborative dynamics in your current project.\n\nDuring this talk I\u2019ll share how you can use git as the magnifier to learn not just about code, to learn about how your team is collaborating together, how to reconstruct parts of your project, understand how your team is building features, how git could gives you the answer to many questions for your team, I\u2019ll share how it\u2019s a powerful tool for new joiners, and how git could become you to a better team player.\n\nAbout Git Merge:\nGit Merge is dedicated to amplifying new voices in the Git community and showcasing the most thought-provoking projects from developers, maintainers, and teams around the world. We address the issue from two fronts:\n\n(1) Sparse checkout: we developed a tool that allow users to specify a list of directories that they need to change, the tool calls bazel query to discover all files in the repository needed to build projects in the given directories and checks out the directories and their dependencies. The tool maintains a private work tree to run Bazel queries and a work tree for each sparse checkout.\n\n(2) FS Monitor: we can share some git performance data without any fsmonitor, with Watchman, with daemon, on macOS vs on Linux for those who are not using sparse checkout"}, {"url": "bx_LGilOuE4", "label": "Jujutsu: A Git-Compatible VCS - Git Merge 2022", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/bx_LGilOuE4/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEGEAs1D28ExRQONnX-uZ3Wf"], "position": 13, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFR0VBczFEMjhFeFJRT05uWC11WjNXZi4yMUQyQTQzMjRDNzMyQTMy", "publishedAt": "2022-10-18", "description": "Presented by Martin von Zweigbergk\n\nJujutsu (jj) can be used as an alternative CLI for Git repos, but it's much more than just a different CLI. It adds many new features, such as undo, anonymous branches, first-class conflicts (stored in commits), and automatic rebasing of descendants on rewrite. It also makes the working copy an actual commit (created automatically), leading to a simpler and more powerful UX than the staging area. The session is going to cover jj's design and features, and our plans for the project at Google.\n\nAbout Git Merge:\nGit Merge is dedicated to amplifying new voices in the Git community and showcasing the most thought-provoking projects from developers, maintainers, and teams around the world. Git Merge 2022 took place at Morgan Manufacturing in Chicago, IL on September 14th and 15th."}, {"url": "i6-z1kFPl0U", "label": "Learn How Git's Code Works - Git Merge 2022", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/i6-z1kFPl0U/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEGEAs1D28ExRQONnX-uZ3Wf"], "position": 14, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFR0VBczFEMjhFeFJRT05uWC11WjNXZi4wOTA3OTZBNzVEMTUzOTMy", "publishedAt": "2022-10-18", "description": "Presented by Jacob Stopak\n\nThis talk discusses the concepts and implementation of Git's very first revision (i.e. Git's initial commit), as published by Linus Torvalds in 2005. The talk explores the actual C code that Linus wrote in 2005 when he developed the initial commit of Git's codebase. Topics covered would be Git's original implementation of file compression, hash functions, Git objects (blobs, trees, commits), the current directory cache (staging area), the structure of Git's original C codebase (which amazingly is only 10 files and ~1000 lines of code), and a demo of Git's original set of commands.\n\nAbout Git Merge:\nGit Merge is dedicated to amplifying new voices in the Git community and showcasing the most thought-provoking projects from developers, maintainers, and teams around the world. For more info, go to http://github.com"}, {"url": "Qcq0WfXz-aM", "label": "Configure version updates in Dependabot #shorts", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Qcq0WfXz-aM/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEG2cjOxhvHNVS4NUYiZPm6z"], "position": 15, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRzJjak94aHZITlZTNE5VWWlaUG02ei41NTZEOThBNThFOUVGQkVB", "publishedAt": "2022-07-19", "description": "You can configure your repository so that Dependabot automatically updates the packages you use. Enable Dependabot version updates by committing a dependabot.yml configuration file to your repository. \n\nAfter you've enabled version updates, you can customize how Dependabot maintains your dependencies by adding further options to the dependabot.yml file. For example, you could:\n\n1. Specify which day of the week to open pull requests for version updates: schedule.day.\n2. Set reviewers, assignees, and labels for each package manager: reviewers, assignees, and labels.\n3. Define a versioning strategy for changes to each manifest file: versioning-strategy.\n4. Change the maximum number of open pull requests for version updates from the default of 5: open-pull-requests-limit.\n5. Open pull requests for version updates to target a specific branch, instead of the default branch: target-branch.\n\nFor all configuration options, check out:\nhttps://docs.github.com/en/code-security/dependabot/dependabot-version-updates/configuration-options-for-the-dependabot.yml-file\n\nPresented by: Andrea Griffiths\n\nAs always, feel free to leave us a comment below and don't forget to subscribe: http://bit.ly/subgithub\n\nThanks!\n\nConnect with us.\nMeetup: https://www.meetup.com/pro/github-virtual-meetup/\nFacebook: http://fb.com/github\nTwitter: http://twitter.com/github\nLinkedIn: http://linkedin.com/company/github\n\nAbout GitHub\nGitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. But with the introduction of native CI/CD to GitHub in 2019 via GitHub Actions, it\u2019s easier than ever to bring CI/CD directly into your workflow right from your repository.\n\nThat\u2019s a great thing. As developers, we\u2019re trained to use peer reviews to make sure our code works. But I\u2019m here to tell you we need to disrupt the peer review. If you\u2019re using Git, GitHub, and GitHub Actions to build a CI/CD pipeline, you should have confidence in your code.\n\nI\u2019m going to walk you through exactly how to build your own CI/CD pipeline, right from your repository on GitHub.\n\nhttps://github.blog/2022-02-02-build-ci-cd-pipeline-github-actions-four-steps/\n\nThanks!\n\nConnect with us.\nFacebook: http://fb.com/github\nTwitter: http://twitter.com/github\nLinkedIn: http://linkedin.com/company/github\n\nAbout GitHub\nGitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. Hear from experts in the field on how they use GitHub to build better software.\n\nSpeaker: Victor Ikechukwu\nhttps://twitter.com/victor_codejs\n\nVictor is a frontend developer and technical writer interested in the JAMStack, and has a knack for breaking down developer concepts to understandable bits for others.\n\nTitle: Docs vs Tooling\nThe Best Approach To Enable Developers to Effectively Use Your (Frontend) Code External documentation is great in supporting developers using our code, but it\u2019s not always enough and doesn't provide an immediate guidance to the developers using the code. Enter Tooling. Tooling refers to the development tools/processes that make our code more maintainable and useable for others. In this talk, I'd elaborate on docs, tooling, and how/why frontend developers can integrate both docs and tooling to enable other developers and themselves to effectively use their code.\n\nSpeaker: Cliff Gor\nhttps://twitter.com/gor_clifford\nStrategic and creative thinker, with the ability to articulate and present\ntechnical matters to all audiences.\n\nAs always, feel free to leave us a comment below and don't forget to subscribe: http://bit.ly/subgithub\n\nThanks!\n\nConnect with us.\nFacebook: http://fb.com/github\nTwitter: http://twitter.com/github\nLinkedIn: http://linkedin.com/company/github\n\nAbout GitHub\nGitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. This month we are focused on Maintainers! Maintainer Month is an opportunity for maintainers to gather and share knowledge and experiences. It\u2019s a time to see how other projects are tackling similar problems. And it\u2019s a time to reflect collectively that the challenges faced aren\u2019t all technical, and the burden on maintainers can come with a lack of boundaries, vacations, or emotional support. Whether you\u2019re celebrating contributions to open source, or reflecting on the particular pains of this line of labor, this is a month to come together.\n\nHosted by GitHub\u2019s own Martins Ewere and Community co-host and GitHub Star Ruth Ikegah.\n\nEvent Program:\n- GitHub News with Martins and Ruth \ud83d\udcfa\n\n- Speaker: Marlene Mhangami\nhttps://twitter.com/marlene_zw\n\nTopic: Maintaining an Open Source Project\nMarlene is a Zimbabwean software engineer, explorer, and speaker based in the city of Harare. Un flujo de trabajo (workflow) es un proceso automatizado configurable compuesto por uno o m\u00e1s trabajos/trabajadores (workers) que pueden ser iniciados por eventos dentro de tus repositorios o por eventos programados.\n\nAprenderemos a configurar y utilizar flujos de trabajo existentes utilizando acciones disponibles en el mercado de acciones de Github y fnalizaremos viendo podemos desarrollar una acci\u00f3n desde cero.\n\nAcerca de nuestro ponente:\nGonzalo Pe\u00f1a-Castellanos\n\nDesarrollador de JupyterLab, trabajando en localizaci\u00f3n e internacionalizaci\u00f3n.\nSoy Ingeniero Civil con MSc. en Hidroinform\u00e1tica y MSc en Ingenier\u00eda Sanitaria que descubri\u00f3 la pasi\u00f3n por el Desarrollo de Software y la Ciencia de Datos lo que me llev\u00f3 a colaborar en diferentes proyectos de c\u00f3digo abierto y eventualmente a unirme a Anaconda, Inc (antes conocida como Continuum Analytics) y actualmente a Quansight, Inc como Ingeniero de Software Senior.\n\nSoy un desarrollador senior de Python y cient\u00edfico de datos (en desarrollo) con experiencia en desarrollo de escritorio (Qt/PyQt), desarrollo web backend (Flask, Tornado, Django, Lektor, MySQL, PostgreSQL, MongoDB), computaci\u00f3n cient\u00edfica (Numpy, Scipy, Pandas, Matplotlib, Dask) y Devops (Amazon Web Services, Heroku). He trabajado como desarrollador en diferentes equipos y como l\u00edder t\u00e9cnico para el proyecto Anaconda Navigator, siguiendo metodolog\u00edas \u00e1giles, basadas en pruebas y con integraci\u00f3n y despliegue continuo. Aunque trabajo principalmente con Python y TypeScript, durante mi carrera como ingeniero he trabajado (en el pasado distante) con otros lenguajes y herramientas, incluyendo C, Java y PHP.\n\nSoy un miembro activo de la comunidad de c\u00f3digo abierto, contribuyendo a diferentes proyectos y l\u00edder en la Comunidad Python Colombia, ayudando a dar forma y organizar comunidades como Django Girls Colombia, Python Bucaramanga, Python Colombia y las Conferencias Python nacionales y latinoamericanas, PyCon Colombia\n(2018, 2019, 2020) y SciPy Latam (2019, 2021, 2022) respectivamente.\n\nSoy un m\u00fasico aficionado (guitarra y teclados), escalador en formaci\u00f3n y piloto certificado de drones. Hablo espa\u00f1ol, ingl\u00e9s y franc\u00e9s con fluidez. "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFR3FrUzdmNW1XYUZpbUdSWEtUZ2Y0bi41MzJCQjBCNDIyRkJDN0VD", "publishedAt": "2021-03-16", "description": "Acompa\u00f1a a Alexandra Bourne, Gerente de Proyectos, y a Jaime Sanchez, Ingeniero de Soporte de GitHub, a aprender acerca de nuevas tendencias en tecnolog\u00eda.\n\nTendremos a varios invitados especiales que compartir\u00e1n mini charlas de 15-20 minutos en temas de tecnolog\u00eda, el uso de Git y GitHub y civismo tecnol\u00f3gico.\n\n5:05 - Comenzar\n\n14:28 - Alejandra Trejo es de Monterrey, M\u00e9xico y actualmente trabaja en Google como ingeniera de software y previamente fue practicante en GitHub. Le apasiona todo lo relacionado al open source y a apoyar a que m\u00e1s mujeres aprendan a programar.\n\nAlejandra nos dar\u00e1 una breve introducci\u00f3n a lo que es GitHub Learning Lab y c\u00f3mo funciona. Hablar\u00e1 un poco de porqu\u00e9 es importante crear m\u00e1s contenido en espa\u00f1ol sobre programaci\u00f3n y c\u00f3mo fue la experiencia de trabajar en este proyecto en GitHub. Finalmente, les ense\u00f1ar\u00e1 como aportar traducciones a los cursos de GitHub Learning Lab.\n\n30:53 - Alvaro Mu\u00f1oz trabaja como investigador de seguridad en GitHub Security Labs, donde ayuda a proteger el software de c\u00f3digo abierto y a educar a los desarrolladores en programaci\u00f3n defensiva. Mu\u00f1oz ha presentado en las mas importantes conferencias de seguridad como BlackHat, DEFCON, RSA, OWASP, etc. y cuenta con varias certificaciones de seguridad de la informaci\u00f3n, incluidas OSCP, GWAPT y CISSP.\nEn seguridad, el \"an\u00e1lisis de variantes\" es el proceso de b\u00fasqueda de vulnerabilidades similares a una conocida. Este proceso sol\u00eda hacerse con herramientas como grep y minuciosas auditor\u00edas de c\u00f3digo manual, pero se puede automatizar con un potente lenguaje de consulta sem\u00e1ntica como CodeQL. En esta charla mostrar\u00e1 c\u00f3mo un an\u00e1lisis de variantes en Nexus Repository Manager termin\u00f3 encontrando muchas otras vulnerabilidades cr\u00edticas, incluida una ejecuci\u00f3n remota de c\u00f3digo (RCE) en la aplicaci\u00f3n Corona-Warn-App de Alemania (la aplicaci\u00f3n de seguimiento de contactos de Alemania).\n\n\n57:20 - Adri\u00e1n Bolonio es Engineering Team Lead, Senior Frontend Developer, y gran defensor de la Accesibilidad Web. Adri\u00e1n es de Madrid, pero desde 2012 vivo y trabajo en Viena (Austria). Cuando no est\u00e1 en la oficina pueden encontrarlo disfrutando de una buena lectura, trabajando en alguna receta o practicando su hobby favorito, viajar.\nCuando desarrollamos una nueva web, a menudo ponemos mucho trabajo en el dise\u00f1o, para que sea bonita y utilizable. Pero muchas veces no pensamos en la experiencia del usuario para las personas con discapacidades. Adri\u00e1n nos hablar\u00e1 acerca de la accesibilidad (a11y) y su importancia y nos ense\u00f1ar\u00e1 a hacer tests automatizados de accesibilidad web, bibliotecas y t\u00e9cnicas para aumentar la cobertura de tests de tu c\u00f3digo con un simple ejemplo con una aplicaci\u00f3n React.\n\nhttps://github.co/Presente-Espa\u00f1ol"}, {"url": "gkhOvhxjeLc", "label": "India Community Meetup - 06 October", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/gkhOvhxjeLc/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEGqkS7f5mWaFimGRXKTgf4n"], "position": 58, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFR3FrUzdmNW1XYUZpbUdSWEtUZ2Y0bi4yMUQyQTQzMjRDNzMyQTMy", "publishedAt": "2020-10-07", "description": "0:19 - Welcome address - Karan Venkatesh - Developer Relations Program Manager, GitHub\n9:05 - Contributing to Open Source through Hacktoberfest - Peeyush Gupta, Sr. Developer Advocate, DigitalOcean\n35:01 - Getting Started Contributing to Open Source - Richa Kumar, Sr. Director of Engineering, GitHub\n59:23 - Road to CNCF & growing a contributor community - Umasankar Mukkara, Co-Founder, OpenEBS project\n1:20:18 - Closing remarks and announcing next month's event"}, {"url": "XqK2pQH6xVw", "label": "GitHub \u00a1Presente! Actualmente es el director de datos de Bitergia, se centra en la calidad de los datos, la b\u00fasqueda de nuevas m\u00e9tricas, el an\u00e1lisis y los estudios de inter\u00e9s para los clientes de Bitergia a trav\u00e9s de la miner\u00eda y el procesamiento de datos. Daniel tiene un doctorado en ingenier\u00eda de software libre de la Universidad Rey Juan Carlos de Madrid, donde se centr\u00f3 en el an\u00e1lisis de patrones de actividad de desarrolladores con errores en la comunidad de Mozilla. Daniel es miembro de la junta directiva y es miembro de InnerSource Commons y de la comunidad CHAOSS.\n\n37:06 - Alfredo Garay\nCharla \"El S\u00edndrome de Impostor\"\nhttps://twitter.com/alfgaraym\nAtr\u00e9vete a salir de tu zona de confort venciendo el s\u00edndrome del impostor.\n\nBio: Coach Ontol\u00f3gico Certificado, orientado a desarrollar habilidades humanas y de management en las personas para alcanzar mejores resultados en sus empresas\n\n1:03:01 - Fernanda Ochoa\nCon un anuncio especial acerca de nuestra comunidad."}, {"url": "BNm5Nu75TVE", "label": "GitHub Presente Evento virtual que re\u00fane devs e profissionais de tech do Brasil", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/BNm5Nu75TVE/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEGqkS7f5mWaFimGRXKTgf4n"], "position": 62, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFR3FrUzdmNW1XYUZpbUdSWEtUZ2Y0bi4xMkVGQjNCMUM1N0RFNEUx", "publishedAt": "2021-04-21", "description": "Esta edi\u00e7\u00e3o do GitHub Presente vem recheada de conte\u00fado que voc\u00ea n\u00e3o vai querer perder! Venha participar de workshops com devs e profissionais da \u00e1rea de tecnologia no Brasil!\n\nO \u201cChester\u201d (Carlos Nascimento, @chesterbr) \u00e9 brasileiro-canadense e Engenheiro de Software no GitHub h\u00e1 quatro anos, trabalhando e se divertindo com programa\u00e7\u00e3o desde os anos 90 em empresas (Shopify, iG, Apontador e outras), no governo, empreendendo, em projetos de software livre (miniTruco, cruzalinhas) e onde mais puder criar e consertar coisas para melhorar a vida das pessoas.\n\nNossos convidados deste m\u00eas:\n\n5:02 - Start\n\n13:56 - Osanam Giordane\n\nMeu nome \u00e9 Osanam Giordane e sou um Arquiteto Cloud focado em ferramentas DevOps, sou premiado pela Microsoft como Microsft MVP na categoria Cloud and Datacenter Management e associado a ONG MTAC (More technology available for the community) focada em ser refer\u00eancia em inova\u00e7\u00e3o para o terceiro setor, criando solu\u00e7\u00f5es totalmente filantr\u00f3picas, para conectar pessoas em um futuro movido por tecnologia e para todos!\n\nSou do Brasil e Estou trabalhando principalmente com Cloud Computing (Azure | AWS | GCP), Infrastructure as Code (IaC), CI/CD e demais ferramentas DevOps.\n\nSou profissional de tecnologia da informa\u00e7\u00e3o desde o ano 2000!\n\nAmor por aprendizado de tecnologia e a possibilidade de repassar conhecimento!\n\n35:05 - Gabriel Nepomuceno\n\nGabriel \u00e9 Principal Software Engineer na Microsoft respons\u00e1vel pela transi\u00e7\u00e3o para a nuvem de algumas das maiores corpora\u00e7\u00f5es do planeta. That's why productivity is such an important issue. And that's where project planning comes in.\n\nProject planning is a critical tool for organizations of all sizes. It can help you ship products faster, increase efficiency, and improve communication among team members. In this demo, Senior Software Engineer Jed Verity will show you how to use GitHub Projects to boost productivity in your organization. You'll learn how to create and manage projects, set deadlines, and track progress. You'll also learn how to use project planning to resolve conflicts and make better decisions about priorities. By the end of this talk, you'll have a better understanding of how project planning with GitHub Projects can help your organization succeed.\n\nAbout our Speaker:\n\nHaving been both a manager and engineer at GitHub, not to mention a lifelong productivity nerd, Jed is deeply interested in tools and practices that help teams and individuals do their best work. The code in ORCA will trigger different midi notes in different channels of Ableton loaded with synths and drum machines. In the background, he will tweak the knobs on Ableton to design his sound for the code.\n\n\nAs always, feel free to leave us a comment below and don't forget to subscribe: http://bit.ly/subgithub\n\nThanks!\n\nConnect with us.\nFacebook: http://fb.com/github\nTwitter: http://twitter.com/github\nLinkedIn: http://linkedin.com/company/github\n\nAbout GitHub\nGitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. It uses PyTorch to power deep neural networks which embed natural language queries and code snippets into vectors. Using nearest neighbor search, it can determine which code snippets are most similar to a given query or another code snippet. What's more, a tool like CodeSnippetSearch can allow you to easily explore unfamiliar code focusing on the semantics without getting bogged down in the syntax, which is especially useful when onboarding a new developer onto a project.\n\nAs always, feel free to leave us a comment below and don't forget to subscribe: http://bit.ly/subgithub\n\nThanks!\n\nConnect with us.\nFacebook: http://fb.com/github\nTwitter: http://twitter.com/github\nLinkedIn: http://linkedin.com/company/github\n\nAbout GitHub\nGitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. Such was the case for Intuit in early 2018 when the company set out on its innersource journey. At the time, its engineering teams were using different structures for their repositories, different best-practices for documentation, and different workflows for code reviews. Today, the company is well on its way to company-wide adoption of innersource, with more than half of its repositories open for contribution, and a goal to open them all. In this talk, Intuit will share a model that enterprise companies can use to teach global engineering teams to work as an innersource community. With easier ways to add features, manage dependancies, and build new skills, you'll come away with the knowledge your team needs to build better software faster.\n\nFor more from GitHub Universe 2020, visit https://githubuniverse.com\n\nAs always, feel free to leave us a comment below and don't forget to subscribe: http://bit.ly/subgithub\n\nThanks!\n\nConnect with us.\nFacebook: http://fb.com/github\nTwitter: http://twitter.com/github\nLinkedIn: http://linkedin.com/company/github\n\nAbout GitHub\nGitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. You start to wonder, \u201cis there a better way I could have managed my secret?\u201d In this talk, you\u2019ll learn how to manage secrets in your infrastructure pipeline using HashiCorp Vault and Terraform with GitHub Actions. By using Vault\u2019s dynamic secrets engines, you can rotate, audit, and manage the lifecycle of your infrastructure account keys and API tokens. For more info, go to http://github.com"}, {"url": "oPAtbWK9oyY", "label": "Observability: superpowers for developers - GitHub Universe 2020", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/oPAtbWK9oyY/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEE7cFFLKAOHUHW1XKVUooqt"], "position": 3, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRTdjRkZMS0FPSFVIVzFYS1ZVb29xdC41MjE1MkI0OTQ2QzJGNzNG", "publishedAt": "2020-12-10", "description": "Presented by Christine Yen, CEO/Cofounder, Honeycomb\n\nThe adoption of observability practices has allowed us to understand our production software in a whole new way. When viewed from the perspective of a developer, it can feel like gaining superpowers. When observability is folded into the development process itself, it represents the potential for a beautifully virtuous cycle: Production stops being just where our development code runs into issues, and it becomes where part of our development process lives. This talk will cover how to implement observability practices (from your tools and from your humans) and what you can achieve as a result.\n\nFor more from GitHub Universe 2020, visit https://githubuniverse.com\n\nAs always, feel free to leave us a comment below and don't forget to subscribe: http://bit.ly/subgithub\n\nThanks!\n\nConnect with us.\nFacebook: http://fb.com/github\nTwitter: http://twitter.com/github\nLinkedIn: http://linkedin.com/company/github\n\nAbout GitHub\nGitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. Millions of people use GitHub to build amazing things together. Through code scanning, it analyzes your pull requests and flags up security issues as early as possible. But who creates these CodeQL queries and how do they know what to look for? For the last two years, a community of security researchers have been contributing to CodeQL queries that formalize their security knowledge. Queries written by independent researchers, enterprise security teams, and everyone in between now help protect all CodeQL users from security vulnerabilities. In this session you'll find out more about this community, the bounty programs, and the tools they use to help you secure your code. And how you can become part of it!\n\nFor more from GitHub Universe 2020, visit https://githubuniverse.com\n\nAs always, feel free to leave us a comment below and don't forget to subscribe: http://bit.ly/subgithub\n\nThanks!\n\nConnect with us.\nFacebook: http://fb.com/github\nTwitter: http://twitter.com/github\nLinkedIn: http://linkedin.com/company/github\n\nAbout GitHub\nGitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. With auto-merge, pull requests can be automatically merged when all requirements for merging are met. No more waiting for long checks to finish just so you can press the merge button!\n\nTo use auto-merge, a repository maintainer or admin must first toggle on the repository setting to allow auto-merge. Then any user with write permission can enable or disable auto-merge by navigating to the pull request page.\n\nNote that auto-merge can only be enabled on pull requests that target a branch protected by required reviews or status checks.\n\nLearn more about pull request auto-merge:\n\nhttps://docs.github.com/en/github/collaborating-with-issues-and-pull-requests/automatically-merging-a-pull-request\n\nAs always, feel free to leave us a comment below and don't forget to subscribe: http://bit.ly/subgithub\n\nThanks!\n\nConnect with us.\nFacebook: http://fb.com/github\nTwitter: http://twitter.com/github\nLinkedIn: http://linkedin.com/company/github\n\nAbout GitHub\nGitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. I'll show how legislation such as Europe's GDPR have made it easier for us to build our own personal analytics platforms, and discuss the way forward towards a world where we can empower even non-nerds to finally take control of their personal data.\n\nAbout Simon Willison\nSimon is the creator of Datasette, an open source tool for exploring and publishing data.\n\nDatasette is based on Simon's experiences working as a data journalist at the UK's Guardian newspaper.\n\nSimon is also a co-creator of the Django web framework. It\u2019s pretty exciting: I will sketch the context and describe our progress.\n\nBut I will focus on one particularly exciting development: Project Quantum. So-called \u201cdiagnostic questions\u201d are multiple choice questions that promote learning (rather than measurement). But it\u2019s hard to know which ones work well, and which don\u2019t. In partnership with an ed-tech startup (Eedi) we now have hundreds of millions of data points and are beginning to apply both statistics (Rasch analysis) and machine learning (variational autoencoders) to distilling insights from this data.\n\nAbout Simon Peyton-Jones\nI fell in love with functional programming when I was 20, and I am still in love today. I helped design Haskell, and I spend a lot of time on GHC, Haskell's most widely-used compiler (including inside GitHub).\n\nI got involved in education because I was dissatisfied with the computing education my children experienced. It has turned out to be much more rewarding than I expected, and I hope to share some of that excitement in my talk.\n\nTwitter: @SIMONPJ0\nGitHub: SIMONPJ\nWeb: https://research.microsoft.com/~simonpj\n\nLearn more about the OCTO Speaker series here: https://octo.github.com/"}, {"url": "yP028rbR_t4", "label": "OCTO Speaker Series Episode 1: Dr. Denae Ford Robinson", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/yP028rbR_t4/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEEAQzMJJR2nAkIOGuyhSu0n"], "position": 8, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRUFRek1KSlIybkFrSU9HdXloU3Uwbi4yODlGNEE0NkRGMEEzMEQy", "publishedAt": "2020-08-26", "description": "Golden Rules of Building Online Communities that Matter: Online communities for programmers, like Stack Overflow and GitHub, have norms that are not obvious nor inclusive to the 50 million programmers visiting monthly.\n\nIn this talk, Dr. Denae Ford Robinson, Senior Researcher - Microsoft Research will 1) offer a perspective of understanding what can inhibit participation, 2) describe what mechanisms developers are using to alleviate their own frustrations with communities, and 3) outline what on-platform mechanisms can intervene to better support engagement based on rigorous research.\n\nLearn more about the OCTO Speaker series here: https://octo.github.com/\n\nAs always, feel free to leave us a comment below and don't forget to subscribe: http://bit.ly/subgithub\r\n\r\nThanks!\r\n\r\nConnect with us.\r\nFacebook: http://fb.com/github\r\nTwitter: http://twitter.com/github\r\nGoogle+: http://google.com/+github\r\nLinkedIn: http://linkedin.com/company/github\r\n\r\nAbout GitHub\r\nGitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. I'll explain \"property-based testing\", which combines test case generation, test case simplification, and using properties to specify your code. I'll show you what you need to think about to make it work in practice, and tell you tales of some of our more entertaining bugs.\n\nAbout John Hughes\nI've loved functional programming all my career; I wrote \"Why Functional Programming Matters\", a manifesto for the field, way back in the eighties. I urged lazy evaluation on John Backus (but failed to persuade him). I was a co-designer of Haskell. I moved to Sweden, home of the Lazy ML compiler, in the nineties, and at the turn of the millennium I co-invented property-based testing. I co-founded a startup in 2006 to bring PBT to industry, and I've learned to love (other peoples') buggy software! Click on the settings tab and then scroll down on that initial page until you get to the features section here and just click the box for discussions. It's as easy as that and then when you scroll back up you're going to see that there's now a discussions item on your repo.\"\n\n\"Fundamentally discussions are designed to be different from issues so when we think of issues. They're to talk about an issue right so they're generally designed to be somewhat focused we're talking about a specific thing often in association with the work or the code that we're actually working on, and issues often lead to pull requests right so very much about specific aspects of our workflow. Discussions on the other hand are intended to be much more free form much more open and much more wide ranging. For example this might be a way for you to interact with your user community around broader questions like how do i use your tool, what are the pros and cons of your tool, what are the philosophical implications of what you're writing here.\"\n\n\"Now we're going to go on and check out possibly the most exciting the most complex and I think the most far-reaching and impactful of the features that we released at GitHub Universe and that's something called GitHub Codespaces. \n\nNow before I get into that spoiler alert we're going to talk about a demo that we're working on here that really exercises a lot of the other features that we released at universe and that we released since then so if you weren't aware we now support multiple really as many environments as you like. Would it be possible to build an editor that combined great performance with ease of use? It was also important to give users of all frameworks, the ability to build an editor by picking and choosing their desired building blocks.\n\nIn order to meet these goals, ProseMirror was picked as the best choice for the core editor layer. The second decision was to base the structure of the editor on blocks of functionality called Extensions. Each extension would be designed to fulfill a specific purpose in the editor. Due to this structure, users would be able to craft a fully custom implementation.\n\nJoin @bdougieYO and @ifiokjr in learning the latest in text editor magic with ProseMirror and React.\n\n0:00 - Start\n1:25 - What is remirror?\n2:42 - Demo\n11:53 - Automating pre-releases with GitHub Actions\n18:09 - Contributors added to the funding.yml\n\nAs always, feel free to leave us a comment below and don't forget to subscribe: http://bit.ly/subgithub\n\nThanks!\n\nConnect with us.\nFacebook: http://fb.com/github\nTwitter: http://twitter.com/github\nLinkedIn: http://linkedin.com/company/github\n\nAbout GitHub\nGitHub is the best place to share code with friends, co-workers, classmates, and complete strangers. He is \nactive across the digital arts as researcher and practitioner, \norganising hundreds of events including Sheffield's \"\"AlgoMech\"\" festival \nof algorithmic and mechanical movement. Whether you're a hobbyist, an open source maintainer, or an organization, the single truth remains: We can\u2019t buy time. Success is often determined by how efficiently we are using our time. In order to increase our efficiencies, we turned to GitHub Actions to automate our workflows for both the software and hardware we produce. We are now able to reprogram our Arduino board, test the input/output of the hardware, and then send the results back to GitHub Actions. We can completely automate not just a continuous integration of the software but also of the hardware using solely online tools. In this talk, we'll run through the workflows Arduino has implemented with GitHub Actions and show attendees ways that they can take the first steps into bringing GitHub Actions into their development cycle.\n\nGitHub Satellite: A community connected by code\n\nOn May 6th, we threw a free virtual event featuring developers working together on the world\u2019s software, announcements from the GitHub team, and inspiring performances by artists who code.\n\nMore information: https://githubsatellite.com\nSchedule: https://githubsatellite.com/schedule/"}, {"url": "kCo0OJZHRX8", "label": "Credential mitigation in large-scale organizations - Or, Developers' perception of software dependencies - GitHub Satellite 2020", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/GtLZp6DbcE4/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEH4Ki3DGF19QGOQ6wjcsvva"], "position": 5, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFSDRLaTNER0YxOVFHT1E2d2pjc3Z2YS45ODRDNTg0QjA4NkFBNkQy", "publishedAt": "2020-05-07", "description": "Presented by Ivan Pashchenko, Postdoctoral Research Fellow, University of Trento\n\nSecurity vulnerabilities introduced by software dependencies can lead to severe incidents. Take for example, the Equifax breach, when the private data of more than 143 million people became publicly available due to a security vulnerability in an outdated software dependency. Despite the fact that GitHub Security Alerts and other tools allow software developers to check free open-source dependencies, developers still aren't paying enough attention to their security. In this talk, Ivan will discuss the perceptions of developers coming from 25 companies located in nine countries\u2014and will present the insights on their practices, from the selection of software dependencies and updating of software dependencies to automating the dependency-management process and the mitigation of bugs and vulnerabilities in dependencies where a fixed version doesn't exist. Armed with this new knowledge, participants will discover the implications of the most popular dependency-management strategies, and from there will be able to improve the dependency management of their own software projects.\n\nGitHub Satellite: A community connected by code\n\nOn May 6th, we threw a free virtual event featuring developers working together on the world\u2019s software, announcements from the GitHub team, and inspiring performances by artists who code.\n\nMore information: https://githubsatellite.com\nSchedule: https://githubsatellite.com/schedule/"}, {"url": "SsP8UEF8uRM", "label": "Open source for good: COVID-19 Responses - GitHub Satellite 2020", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/SsP8UEF8uRM/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEH4Ki3DGF19QGOQ6wjcsvva"], "position": 6, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFSDRLaTNER0YxOVFHT1E2d2pjc3Z2YS5EMEEwRUY5M0RDRTU3NDJC", "publishedAt": "2020-05-07", "description": "With Linda Raftree, Alexandra Grigore, Clayton Sims, and Mike Endale\nModerated by Mala Kumar\n\nGitHub Satellite: A community connected by code\n\nOn May 6th, we threw a free virtual event featuring developers working together on the world\u2019s software, announcements from the GitHub team, and inspiring performances by artists who code.\n\nMore information: https://githubsatellite.com\nSchedule: https://githubsatellite.com/schedule/"}, {"url": "fZKQI-ER6xw", "label": "Defenders guide to cloud native infrastructure security - GitHub Satellite 2020", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/fZKQI-ER6xw/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEH4Ki3DGF19QGOQ6wjcsvva"], "position": 7, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFSDRLaTNER0YxOVFHT1E2d2pjc3Z2YS40NzZCMERDMjVEN0RFRThB", "publishedAt": "2020-05-07", "description": "Presented by Madhu Akula\n\n\"While DevOps teams have moved toward cloud, containers, Kubernetes, serverless, and cloud-native infrastructure, security teams are still catching up. GitHub and HashiCorp are working closely to build an end-to-end DevOps workflow encompassing the entire application development lifecycle. Together we help provide a powerful CI/CD solution that prevents developers and operators from having to wait for their respective tasks to be completed, accelerating delivery. Did you know that a booklet about innersource is the single most downloaded non-code asset on public GitHub? Since the rise of GitHub Enterprise, companies are increasingly experimenting with innersource inside their firewalls. Seems like a no-brainer, doesn't it? Most long-established companies need more collaboration and full-stack knowledge (and fewer information silos, resulting resource bottlenecks, \"not-invented-here\" re-inventions of the wheel, lack of innovation, and all the other un-necessarily wasteful proprietary practices that contribute to poor quality software and low engineering employee morale). Meanwhile, FOSS developers as a rule feel empowered to \"scratch their own itches\" and therefore suffer from few of these proprietary company woes. But as the FOSS movement has grown, there are cracks in sustainability starting to show in the form of maintainer burnout, lack of sufficient or appropriate corporate support for FOSS, and a real shortage of people willing and able to lead FOSS into the future. So how can innersource help FOSS Sustainability? Learn from someone who is thinking about how to grow the pool of qualified FOSS developers and to improve corporate support for FOSS basically since the term open source was coined. You'll hear about specific actions every developer and every company can take to improve software engineering, whether FOSS or proprietary, and help sustain the precious FOSS ecosystem through the next generation.\n\nGitHub Satellite: A community connected by code\n\nOn May 6th, we threw a free virtual event featuring developers working together on the world\u2019s software, announcements from the GitHub team, and inspiring performances by artists who code.\n\nMore information: https://githubsatellite.com\nSchedule: https://githubsatellite.com/schedule/"}, {"url": "XwKTUji5HtY", "label": "Securing the software supply chain together - GitHub Satellite 2020", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/XwKTUji5HtY/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEH4Ki3DGF19QGOQ6wjcsvva"], "position": 17, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFSDRLaTNER0YxOVFHT1E2d2pjc3Z2YS41MjE1MkI0OTQ2QzJGNzNG", "publishedAt": "2020-05-07", "description": "Presented by Maya Kaczorowski, Product Manager, Software Supply Chain Security, GitHub\n\nWriting secure code is hard in its own right, but understanding what vulnerabilities exist in your code\u2014 and how to keep up to date with the latest patches\u2014is daunting for even the most sophisticated software teams. They examined 10,000 open source Java components that were published to Maven Central and hosted on GitHub. They combined team and project performance metrics from GitHub, popularity data from Maven Central, and vulnerability and dependency data from Sonatype to examine what properties are shared by exemplary open source teams. They discuss these findings, including the differences we see between exemplary small teams and large teams, the fact that popularity does not predict security, and how remarkably difficult it is to keep dependencies patched while being \u201calmost\u201d up-to-date. They also highlight the organizational and technology practices they observe among exemplar open source teams, which release new versions 2x more frequently and remediate security vulnerabilities 3x more quickly, all while delivering a level of value that makes them standouts in terms of popularity and adoption.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. This is an excuse to not write documentation or justify the absence of it. In my work with many teams, the lack of documentation is often a symptom of high technical debt.\n\nWhat if we could turn this around and use documentation like a driver for positive culture change and start paying the critical technical debt? This approach not only helps teams to faster identify areas that need critical support but also brings more empathy to the table.\n\nIn this talk, Tania draws on experiences using documentation as a weapon for positive culture and process change in machine learning and scientific computing environments. She focuses on the processes and approaches that enable the creation of documentation for data scientists, infrastructure, and software engineering teams, and clients.\n\nBy the end of the talk, you'll learn efficient techniques to make documentation a first-class citizen in your development cycles\u2014and leave with one or two tricks to convince even the most reluctant developer to document code.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. CodeQL is a tool many security research teams around the world use to perform semantic analysis of code, and we\u2019ve used it ourselves to find over 100 reported CVEs in some of the most popular open source projects.\n\nWe\u2019re also launching the GitHub Advisory Database, a public database of advisories created on GitHub, plus additional data curated and mapped to packages tracked by the GitHub dependency graph.\n\nFor more information, check out our blog post: https://github.blog/2019-11-14-announcing-github-security-lab-securing-the-worlds-code-together/\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. This session will dig into case studies in Europe of how public policy has supported security, or inadvertently threatened to make software more fragile, including how these policies came about, how they impact software security, and how developers influenced the policies. We\u2019ll also cover how developers and industry are working with policymakers and governments to ensure policy supports rather than undermines security and trust, and what you can do as a developer, team member, and citizen to help. \n\nAbout GitHub Satellite 2019\nA community connected by code\n\nExplore our interconnected community\u2014and how collaboration turns ideas into innovations.\n\nJoin us in November at San Francisco's Palace of Fine Arts for GitHub Universe - https://githubuniverse.com/"}, {"url": "bFNqaoHSUIQ", "label": "Maintaining the maintainers: supporting open source tools - GitHub Satellite 2019", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/bFNqaoHSUIQ/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEFXbNHpObS6VQJPI2sibuwn", "PL0lo9MOBetEEII_l3yOUQIrVsnEmYAP16"], "position": 7, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRlhiTkhwT2JTNlZRSlBJMnNpYnV3bi45ODRDNTg0QjA4NkFBNkQy", "publishedAt": "2019-05-30", "description": "Presented by Don Goodman-Wilson, Developer Advocate, EMEA, GitHub\nFloor Drees, Product Marketing Manager, Microsoft\nK Rain Leander, OpenStack Liaison, Red Hat\nMehdi Medjaoui, President, Les Mainteneurs\n\nThis panel will debate whether formalized support like an accelerator program for maintainers could provide motivation in the face of these challenges or if the risks of corporatism outweigh the benefits. We host Android, which contains huge binary assets and employs over 1000 distinct repositories, and Chromium, a monorepo with more than 1750 unique committers last year. Both projects see high volumes of code review traffic and employ significant automation (build bots, auto mergers). We see bursts of greater than 20 updates/second in individual repositories, and a bug fix in one branch can trigger a cascade of automated updates to other branches and repositories.\n\nThis talk will provide tales from the trenches of seeing Git stretched to new limits, the work that has motivated, and how Google monitors its hosting service to ensure Git can continue to scale.\"\n\nAbout GitMerge\nGit Merge is the pre-eminent Git-focused conference: a full-day offering technical content and user case studies, plus a day of workshops for Git users of all levels. Yet, the vast majority of AAA game studios still use Perforce, SVN, and other more traditional systems. It\u2019s not for a lack of desire, rather, game developers have a unique set of constraints and workflows that make Git unsuitable for the task.\n\nThis talk will illustrate how game workflows are unique, why Git doesn\u2019t currently support these workflows (even with LFS), and introduce a new tool, Git Global Graph, that strives to build a path for even the largest AAA developer to use Git. They mustered the patience and the energy to teach Git to yours truly. They did it in stages: they started by how to clone a repository and how to check out its branches, taught me about remotes and how to create my own branches, how to commit my changes, and the etiquette of good commit messages. One glorious day, they decided I was ready to push to a remote repository. By golly I felt powerful. I had mastered Git's mysteries!\n\nBecoming familiar with Git's basic concepts and commands took the best part of 2 years, but it was worth every minute. As a designer, learning Git made me more resilient, more independent and more useful to my development team. Learning Git made me a better designer.\n\nIn this talk, I will try to convince developers that they should invest time and effort in teaching Git to the designers they work with, what they have to gain from it, and how to go about it. \n\nAbout GitMerge\nGit Merge is the pre-eminent Git-focused conference: a full-day offering technical content and user case studies, plus a day of workshops for Git users of all levels. Moda is a set of tools, practices, and ideas for running software on Kubernetes. We\u2019ll share how we approached big infrastructure changes, what has worked well, and why we made the decisions we did. Our success is rooted in treating infrastructure like a product, remembering that we build tools to enable other developers, and focusing on what can help them build the future of software.\n\nThis talk is about the big picture, not the day-to-day details, so you won\u2019t need prior knowledge of containers or Kubernetes to participate or benefit.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. Sessions cover topics from team culture to open source software across industries and technologies.\n\nFor more information on GitHub Universe, check the website:\nhttps://githubuniverse.com"}, {"url": "90JWZnuf7xQ", "label": "API mashup: Combining APIs using GraphQL schema stitching - GitHub Universe 2018", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/90JWZnuf7xQ/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEGYg7aCEDBBsM6AX1nZ4Dkp"], "position": 3, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFR1lnN2FDRURCQnNNNkFYMW5aNERrcC41MjE1MkI0OTQ2QzJGNzNG", "publishedAt": "2018-11-07", "description": "Presented by Rouven We\u00dfling, Developer Evangelist (Contentful).\n\nBy stitching together multiple GraphQL schemas we can take away the overhead of having to remember where data is located and how to resolve references between them. (Yes.) Not soon after, Microsoft launched an AI chatbot experiment, called Tay, which shut down when the software began spewing hateful speech online. One of the known fears of AI and machine learning is the notion of algorithmic bias, which can create or indirectly allow machines to learn prejudiced behavior. In this talk, we will explore what it really means to \u201cteach\u201d a computer to have prejudices, and what can happen product managers, designers, and engineers are not cognizant of their own biases. Appropriate for both technical and non-technical audiences. Maybe we studied some common code smells and learned about the things that we should be avoiding, but memorizing the rules doesn\u2019t automatically lead to fixing all problems. In this talk, we explore how you can use GitHub to recognize and address violations to each of the SOLID principles. Using diffs, commit history and pull requests you can learn to recognize patterns in code that point to problems. These same tools can help you correct those issues and write more maintainable code.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. As someone with Young Onset Parkinson's Disease, I'm personally familiar with how my working conditions, the attitudes of my colleagues, and my ability to disclose has affected the course of my disease. The theme of this talk is about how an empathetic, positive, and flexible work atmosphere is beneficial for people living with chronic disease, based on my personal account. Being productive and thriving at GitHub despite having Young Onset Parkinson's Disease has largely depended on working with empathetic people, but also the ability to work remotely, flexibility, and ultimately feel supported enough to disclose to those I work with. Companies can foster an atmosphere of trust that allows those dealing with chronic illness to self care, whether they choose to disclose or not.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. These are mantras of the tech and design industry. They praise speed and hard work but overlook a core element: people. When building software, we devote hundreds of hours to planning, organizing, building, and launching, but we often only spend a very small fraction of that same time thinking about the people responsible for those activities. Soft skills and emotional intelligence are critical components to building great software. In general, I have found technical audiences do not get as much exposure to these topics as they should. Understanding each other and knowing practical ways to keep each other motivated and encouraged will help us go beyond what our individual technical skills can accomplish. Let's talk about how we can proactively care for our team with the same passion we use when caring for our software. This vastly simplifies our infrastructure setup and maintenance, and gives us powerful primitives on which to build a collaborative content editing system used by writers, designers, photographers, editors, and even web developers. In this talk you will learn: how The New York Times uses the GitHub API to store documents in the CMS's intermediate format, how we support collaborative editing via the GitHub API, how we catalog our posts via the GitHub API, how we are able to support legacy (\"custom\") development at the same time, and how the GitHub ecosystem, e.g. CI services empower our CMS even further.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. This is true, but at this level, not very actionable. Over our years of building and deploying tools to development teams, we have found that providing the right tools can act as a catalyst for positive culture change. When you provide the right tools to your development teams at scale, you show that you\u2019re serious about changing the way they work. When you help teams learn and master the modern practices that the tools enable, your teams get better at their craft. Your investment in tools and practices help create an environment that attracts and retains top talent. This is all easier said than done, and in this 40 minute panel discussion Bill Higgins, IBM Distinguished Engineer, along with Jason Warner, SVP of Technology of GitHub, discuss concrete strategies for rolling out great tools at scale, including: choosing the right tools, finding and empowering user champions, enabling effective continuous learning (in the context of doing work), gaining the support of senior leadership. Bill and Jason have many years of experience building and deploying tools, and now work closely together on the evolution of GitHub for Business and using GitHub at IBM.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. These applications had a patchwork of tools such as build and deployment automation, monitoring, alerting, and load testing, but with very little consistency and lots of gaps. This talk will dive into our approach to infrastructure automation, which involved integrating our GitHub repositories with automation tools through a common infrastructure database. This automation tracks required actions for service owners through GitHub Issues, and generates pull requests for common configuration and software changes. This talk will summarize lessons learned and how to leverage GitHub APIs and web hooks to build similar infrastructure automation tools.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. It has only been out of developer preview but truly shaking up the way front-end and mobile applications are being developed. Getting into open source projects can be a daunting process, and there are a lot of existing tools out there to assist in getting your first open source pull request including Code Triage, IssueHub, and of course firstpr.me. Open Sauced is one more tool to help by providing a platform to organize notes on potential projects the user has not yet contributed to by leveraging the now public GitHub GraphQL API. Every day hundreds of developers are working on it and pushing new code into the single GitHub repo. \n\nHow do you scale, not in the number of requests served per minute, but from the perspective of developer experience? But how to convey a common understanding to this heterogenous group consisting of software, electrical and mechanical engineers and project managers? We need to downsize the reality, transform it to a common denominator without losing the important aspects.\n\nWe\u2019ve developed a training for that: First nuts&bolts of git with real LEGO blocks. Then a simulation game covering a complete round-trip of continuous deployment in conjunction with Scrum: Up to thirty participants contribute software changes to an Arduino car model through a deployment pipeline with unit tests, integration tests, hardware-in-the-loop teststand in order to realize the customer\u2019s new requirements.\n\nAt Satellite 2017, attendees came to exchange cutting edge practices on how to bring together the people and tools you need to build great software. Meanwhile, developers write code on their own machines with text editors and IDEs. \n\nWe can reduce friction and improve workflows by bridging that gap. The GitHub Client Apps team extends GitHub beyond the browser to fill that gap. This team consists of Atom, Electron, Desktop, and Editor Tools. With their data growing rapidly every year, they've realized a need to change their approach to analysing it. This talk covers how they are working with a suite of open source tools to solve this problem. They have mixed popular projects, like Jupyter Notebooks, with new data processing libraries (like Dask) and their own bespoke weather analysis tools (like Iris). They are also opening large volumes of data to the public, which through these tools can be manipulated quickly and easily from the comfort of a web browser.\n \nAt Satellite 2017, attendees came to exchange cutting edge practices on how to bring together the people and tools you need to build great software. Facebook uses Mercurial to host some of the largest, fastest growing distributed version control repositories in the world. Over the past four years, they've dealt with numerous scaling challenges, ranging from the number of commits per minute to creating robust, redundant server infrastructure. Facebook has also introduced significant user experience improvements to make it easier to ramp up new engineers and to make power-user workflows more accessible to everyone.\n\nIn this session, Durham will talk about the specific technical and user experience improvements Facebook has open sourced to handle their growing scale, with an emphasis on the lessons learned that could be valuable to Git and the Git community.\n\nAbout GitMerge\nGit Merge is the pre-eminent Git-focused conference: a full-day offering technical content and user case studies, plus a day of workshops for Git users of all levels. Find out more at git-merge.com"}, {"url": "Q7i_qQW__q4", "label": "Git LFS at Light Speed - Git Merge 2017", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Q7i_qQW__q4/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEGRAJzoTCdco_fOKDfhqaOY"], "position": 7, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFR1JBSnpvVENkY29fZk9LRGZocWFPWS40NzZCMERDMjVEN0RFRThB", "publishedAt": "2017-05-16", "description": "Lars Schneider & Taylor Blau, of AutoDesk and GitHub respectively, discuss recent performance improvements to Git LFS. \n\nGit and its extensions are becoming more popular than ever. However, certain use cases may still be suboptimal. We identified a way to dramatically improve performance in a popular Git extension - LFS (Large File Storage) - that required changes in both Git Core, and the extension itself. Based on our combined experiences we\u2019ll walk you through the process of a successful contribution to each project with the help of mailing lists and Pull Requests. If you have already a bit of Git command line knowledge then this talk will prepare you for your first contribution to Git, an extension, or both.\n\nAbout GitMerge\nGit Merge is the pre-eminent Git-focused conference: a full-day offering technical content and user case studies, plus a day of workshops for Git users of all levels. Git Merge is dedicated to amplifying new voices in the Git community and to showcasing the most thought-provoking projects from contributors, maintainers and community managers around the world. Tim has scoured dark corners of the web, freenode, and social media to uncover mystic aliases that perform every function from automating standup meetings to \"I'm feeling lucky\" searches across the DAG. Dunham\n\nRust is a systems programming language that runs blazingly fast, prevents segfaults, and guarantees thread safety. Behind the scenes, Rust is also a community that nurtures new contributors, consistently enforces its code of conduct, and maintains a high-quality codebase. However there are answers about 'local' knowledge (architecture, domain, release procedures, coding practices, etc.) which are not as easily found. These questions and answers are passed as tribal knowledge from developer to developer. We wanted to find a better way to share this information. Our team introduced a learning repository utilizing GitHub and Markdown, using the same workflow and diligence used for writing software in capturing our 'local' knowledge. This system has made it easier to get new team members onboarded and saves time for our more seasoned developers.\"\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. The Git Infrastructure team runs Git as a distributed service, providing highly available and durable access to repositories, despite frequent hardware and software failures. One key part of the service is Spokes, a self-healing replication, routing, and load-balancing layer built on top of Git. In this talk by Patrick Reynolds, a Senior Systems Engineer at GitHub, he'll discuss how Spokes detects failures and routes around them to provide high availability. Hear about how Spokes uses real-time replication and voting to durably store repository content. Watch as we induce failures and, ideally, no one notices.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. We'll start out by looking at what makes a great pull request, and what barriers people have with sending and receiving them. Next, we'll remove some of those barriers by discussing some code review best practices to ensure the code we're writing is well written and well tested. Lastly, we'll see how and why these pieces are a crucial part of a proper workflow, and what advantages the GitHub Flow has.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. Within a Project, columns can be created and named to represent different categories of work. Issues, pull requests and notes can then be added to and moved around between columns according to the changing needs of a project.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. Sessions cover topics from team culture to open source software across industries and technologies.\n\nFor more information on GitHub Universe, check the website:\nhttps://githubuniverse.com"}, {"url": "8Nvg-MMtN_A", "label": "Lending Privilege - GitHub Universe 2016", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/8Nvg-MMtN_A/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEFf7wmpc2BIToE4UvsjnrZF"], "position": 2, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRmY3d21wYzJCSVRvRTRVdnNqbnJaRi4wMTcyMDhGQUE4NTIzM0Y5", "publishedAt": "2016-09-28", "description": "Diversity and inclusion have become hot topics in technology, but you may not know how you can make a difference. This talk from Anjuan Simmons will help you understand that, no matter your background, you have privilege and can lend it to marginalized groups in tech.\n\nPrivilege is access to societal and economic benefits based on a characteristic you possess. The most well understood forms of privilege are the ones most people don't choose for themselves like parental, racial, gendered, and physical privilege. However, there are also selected privileges like religion, gender identity, and education.\n\nThis session will teach attendees how to lend their privilege. They will learn three types of privilege lending including credibility lending (where you attach your name to a project being undertaken by someone without privilege), access lending (where you provide access to a position, location or event), and expertise lending (where you give the opportunity to be recognized as an expert). These different types of privilege lending will be illustrated through well known examples and concrete examples of how they can play out in the technology industry.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. Sessions cover topics from team culture to open source software across industries and technologies.\n\nFor more information on GitHub Universe, check the website:\nhttps://githubuniverse.com"}, {"url": "UB283wKxiqU", "label": "Managing GitHub at Scale - GitHub Universe 2016", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/UB283wKxiqU/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEFf7wmpc2BIToE4UvsjnrZF"], "position": 3, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRmY3d21wYzJCSVRvRTRVdnNqbnJaRi41MjE1MkI0OTQ2QzJGNzNG", "publishedAt": "2016-09-28", "description": "Todd O'Connor, SCM Architect & Engineer at Adobe, describes how managing a rapidly growing, large scale, GitHub instance provides many challenges to balance end user productivity with enterprise security requirements and server administrative needs.\n\nAdobe's GitHub Enterprise server is a single instance serving over 7,700 users. Todd will touch upon the needs of Adobe's site admins (concerned with server health, bad behavior detection), managers (concerned with metrics and reports), the security team (concerned with log analysis and access), and end users (integrations, user management).\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. Sessions cover topics from team culture to open source software across industries and technologies.\n\nFor more information on GitHub Universe, check the website:\nhttps://githubuniverse.com"}, {"url": "pJFM321_lAs", "label": "Code Review is an Architectural Necessity - GitHub Universe 2016", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/pJFM321_lAs/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEFf7wmpc2BIToE4UvsjnrZF"], "position": 4, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRmY3d21wYzJCSVRvRTRVdnNqbnJaRi4wOTA3OTZBNzVEMTUzOTMy", "publishedAt": "2016-09-28", "description": "Colin Dean, a software engineer with IBM Watson, discusses the benefits and challenges of Code Review within organizations. Code Review is not a new concept, but a specific term for an older concept -- Peer Review -- that focuses the review process on the code under examination instead of the person who submitted it. While Code Review is common in open source projects, organizations developing in private often employ inefficient, frustrating, or virtually non-existent review processes.\n\nThis talk looks at Code Review from an architect's viewpoint, arguing that Code Review is an essential component in a product's architectural plan because of the quality attributes it may provide. It also covers tips and sets expectations for what Code Review can and cannot solve.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. Most of the four learning stages\u2014unconscious incompetence, conscious incompetence, conscious competence and unconscious competence\u2014are bridged by acquiring experience. But the gap between unconscious incompetence to conscious incompetence is where the most discomfort and discouragement occurs.\n\nHelping new developers bridge that void ensures a vibrant, accessible community, and having visible members/mentors in each stage encourages newcomers' learning. This talk illustrates (literally!) how to help new colleagues build this bridge and prevent losing them in the what-do-I-even-Google abyss.\n\nAbout GitHub Universe:\nGitHub Universe is a two-day conference dedicated to the creativity and curiosity of the largest software community in the world. Finally, Chris announces the availability of unlimited private repositories for all paid accounts on GitHub.com. \n\nPrior to GitHub, Chris briefly attended the University of Cincinnati before moving to San Francisco to work as a software developer at CNET Networks on GameSpot, TV.com, and Chow. For more info, go to http://github.com"}, {"url": "vyenmLqJQjs", "label": "Linux Kernel Development, Greg Kroah-Hartman - Git Merge 2016", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/vyenmLqJQjs/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEEm8-hYjdi_A5P2K-eddW47"], "position": 1, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRW04LWhZamRpX0E1UDJLLWVkZFc0Ny41NkI0NEY2RDEwNTU3Q0M2", "publishedAt": "2016-11-16", "description": "The Linux kernel is the largest collaborative software development project ever. This talk will discuss exactly how Linux is developed, how fast it is happening, and how we all try to stay sane keeping up with it (hint, git is the reason).\n\nGreg Kroah-Hartman is a Fellow at the Linux Foundation. He is currently responsible for the stable Linux kernel releases, and is a maintainer of the USB, TTY, and driver core subsystems in the kernel as well as other portions of the codebase that he wishes he could forget about. He is the author of two books about Linux kernel development, both free online, and has written many papers and articles about the Linux kernel."}, {"url": "f7ecUqHxD7o", "label": "Scaling at GitHub, Patrick Reynolds - Git Merge 2016", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/f7ecUqHxD7o/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEEm8-hYjdi_A5P2K-eddW47"], "position": 2, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRW04LWhZamRpX0E1UDJLLWVkZFc0Ny4yODlGNEE0NkRGMEEzMEQy", "publishedAt": "2016-11-16", "description": "The GitHub Systems team provides Git as a fast and reliable service, both as the backend for GitHub.com the website, and directly to users. To do that, we first make Git itself fast and reliable. But we also must consider Git as a distributed application, at the scale of billions of operations per day. Hear about the challenges that presents, and learn about the bespoke tools GitHub has built to monitor, shape, cache, and replicate transactions in our Git service.\n\nNote: In this talk, Patrick refers to DGit, which was an internal codename for the project to distribute the storage of git repositories more efficiently within GitHub's infrastructure. In order to reduce redundancy and potential confusion, GitHub has subsequently renamed the project Spokes.\n\nPatrick Reynolds leads the team at GitHub that runs Git as a service. He has been building tools to monitor and troubleshoot distributed applications for more than ten years: first as an academic research project, then as a product at BlueStripe Software, and most recently for internal use at GitHub."}, {"url": "b3P2efnryfs", "label": "Adopt Git at Scale and Stay Sane, Lars Schneider - Git Merge 2016", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/b3P2efnryfs/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEEm8-hYjdi_A5P2K-eddW47"], "position": 3, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRW04LWhZamRpX0E1UDJLLWVkZFc0Ny4wMTcyMDhGQUE4NTIzM0Y5", "publishedAt": "2016-11-16", "description": "Git is hard to grasp. This is especially true if you've worked for decades with centralized version control systems such as Perforce, CVS or SVN. This talk is about our journey to on-board 4000+ engineers with 200+ different code bases to Git at Autodesk. Amongst other things, Lars will cover how we manage the Git client setup at that scale as well as AutoDesk's experiences with large Git repositories.\n\nLars Schneier is the technical lead for Git at Autodesk, working out of Berlin, Germany. His current work involves migrating large codebases to Git and establishing Git workflows within teams. He is a Git contributor, the author of the ShowInGitHub Xcode plugin, and is an avid kiteboarder."}, {"url": "z2kEpFF8l1Q", "label": "Change Needs Management, Emily Jane Hogbin Westby - Git Merge 2016", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/z2kEpFF8l1Q/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEEm8-hYjdi_A5P2K-eddW47"], "position": 4, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRW04LWhZamRpX0E1UDJLLWVkZFc0Ny41MjE1MkI0OTQ2QzJGNzNG", "publishedAt": "2016-11-16", "description": "For over a decade Emma Jane Hogbin Westby has been teaching people how to use version control systems. Most people she's encountered still find Git hard to learn on their own. In this session you will learn why most approaches to teaching Git fail to appropriately address the adult learner, and what you can do to make the on-boarding experience easier for others. She will touch on adult education best practices, and also share the secrets that make it easier for very large (and corporate) teams to transition to Git.\n\nEmma Jane Hogbin Westby is a member of the field information services development team at United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (UN-OCHA) and the author of the O'Reilly titles Git for Teams and Collaborating with Git."}, {"url": "TG_MxBNCsaQ", "label": "From CLI to GUI: Overcoming Challenges to Advance Git, John Haley & Hamid Shojaee - Git Merge 2016", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/TG_MxBNCsaQ/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEEm8-hYjdi_A5P2K-eddW47"], "position": 5, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRW04LWhZamRpX0E1UDJLLWVkZFc0Ny4wOTA3OTZBNzVEMTUzOTMy", "publishedAt": "2016-11-16", "description": "Git was designed with the command line in mind, but does that hold the application back? John Haley, Product Owner of Axosoft GitKraken and Hamid Shojaee, Founder of Axosoft, argue that the CLI can be complicated and confusing, with a steep learning curve even for developers. That\u2019s why they\u2019ve created a Git client that is not only beautiful and easy-to-use, but actually translates Git concepts into visually understandable processes.\n\nHamid Shojaee is addicted to the high of making great software. He is founder of two tech companies, Axosoft and Pure Chat, and has been a leader in the Arizona tech community for over 20 years.\n\nJohn Haley has been writing software for over 25 years and is currently Product Owner of Axosoft GitKraken. Teams, Kate Heddleston - CodeConf 2015", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/UQYWHQMKOQA/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEGbR9_NlJSHPl0ABEVi8PZz"], "position": 3, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFR2JSOV9ObEpTSFBsMEFCRVZpOFBaei5GM0Q3M0MzMzY5NTJFNTdE", "publishedAt": "2017-06-01", "description": "Argument cultures and critical feedback are rampant on engineering teams, but social science research shows that both are ineffective in achieving their goals. Arguments create oppositional cultures that reward people for asserting dominance over others instead of finding the best solutions. Critical feedback can worsen performance and engender resentment in those who receive it, making employees both unhappy and less effective. \n\nKate Heddleston's talk will focus on the research around arguments and criticism and talk about the ways that people and teams can effectively address these problems.\n\nAbout CodeConf\nCodeConf improves the software community by providing a forum for thought-provoking talks and forging social connections. Chaos Engineering is a best practice for building confidence in distributed systems that run at scale. It is a logical consequence of loosely coupled, reactive, and microservice architectures. Netflix handles about a third of the Internet\u2019s bits at peak, all controlled by a microservice architecture. They use tools like Chaos Monkey and Chaos Kong to induce failures in their production system, but breaking things is just a small part of what Chaos can and will be. Casey surveys the current state of Chaos best practices, and provides a preview of the future of Chaos.\n\nAbout CodeConf\nCodeConf improves the software community by providing a forum for thought-provoking talks and forging social connections. With big projects like Android and Chrome, we need some pretty big hosting infrastructure: we built a custom globally replicated storage layer, added bundles and bitmaps to reduce server load, and built specialized tools like Gerrit Code Review. But working on large Git-based projects is still not as nice as we'd like it to be. In this talk I'll discuss what we've done to make large projects happy at Google, and what we hope to do to make large projects happy everywhere."}, {"url": "xYhHi8yK-Is", "label": "Teaching People Git, Emma Jane Hogbin Westby - Git Merge 2015", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/xYhHi8yK-Is/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEFDjSJ-QTlgsBEHpd6XnaA-"], "position": 2, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRkRqU0otUVRsZ3NCRUhwZDZYbmFBLS4xMkVGQjNCMUM1N0RFNEUx", "publishedAt": "2015-05-12", "description": "For over a decade Emma Jane Hogbin Westby has been teaching people how to use version control systems. She has carefully updated her approach over the years based on learner feedback, and adult education best practices. But no matter what enhancements she makes, most people still find Git really freaking hard to learn on their own. In this session you will learn why most approaches to teaching Git fail to appropriately address the adult learner. You will learn how to modify your own approach to teaching Git so that others catch on quicker. Finally, you will explore some of the next steps that might be available to the Git community to help change Git from the inside-out--lowering the bar to entry and making Git a more pleasant experience for everyone who uses it. We'll talk about locking and transmission strategies as well as our current work in the area."}, {"url": "MPwRnpzmMI8", "label": "Infrastructure as Code: Manage your Architecture with Git, Danilo Poccia - Git Merge 2015", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/MPwRnpzmMI8/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEFDjSJ-QTlgsBEHpd6XnaA-"], "position": 8, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFRkRqU0otUVRsZ3NCRUhwZDZYbmFBLS41MjE1MkI0OTQ2QzJGNzNG", "publishedAt": "2015-05-12", "description": "With the AWS Cloud you have an on-demand, programmable infrastructure that you can manage using tools and practices from software development. You can create resources when you need and dispose of them when you don\u2019t. Using Amazon CloudFormation you can describe your architecture in text files. To change your infrastructure, you edit those files. Having application and infrastructure code together in a single, robust, versioned repository like Git gives a lot of advantages. Using AWS Elastic Beanstalk you can link your Git branches to different infrastructure environments (e.g. test, production) and automate deployments. You can create test environments on-demand, even for a short time. Instead of continuously update your resources, you can recreate them quickly from scratch, simplifying lifecycle management and making deployments immutable. As a result, you have more time to focus on the unique features of your application."}, {"url": "SCNWWfXpCw0", "label": "GitHub Integrations \u2022 JIRA", "imagen": "https://i.ytimg.com/vi/SCNWWfXpCw0/mqdefault.jpg", "playlistId": ["PL0lo9MOBetEH5HI-GkdjfMBcUMBpw364S"], "position": 0, "type": "video", "id": "UEwwbG85TU9CZXRFSDVISS1Ha2RqZk1CY1VNQnB3MzY0Uy41NkI0NEY2RDEwNTU3Q0M2", "publishedAt": "2014-07-15", "description": "If you're already using the JIRA Issue tracker and would like to integrate it with GitHub, this quick tutorial will get you on your way. GitHub is the software community's favorite collaboration platform and is known for its easy integration with other tools using its RESTful API.
